metadata.description: Comprehensive plant and disease database for crop disease detection system

soil_requirements.organic_matter: Rich in organic matter, 3-5% content ideal
soil_requirements.depth_requirement: Minimum 3 feet for proper root development

weather_requirements.humidity_range: Moderate humidity with good air circulation essential
weather_requirements.sunlight_hours: 6-8 hours daily for optimal fruit development
weather_requirements.frost_tolerance: Cold hardy, requires winter chill hours
weather_requirements.chill_hours: 400-1000 hours below 45°F required for proper flowering

watering: Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth
Provide 1-2 inches of water per week during growing season
Reduce watering before harvest to concentrate flavors
Avoid overhead watering to prevent disease
fertilization: Apply balanced fertilizer (10-10-10) in early spring
Supplement with compost annually in fall
Avoid excessive nitrogen which promotes disease
Side-dress with compost in mid-summer
pruning: Prune annually during dormant season (late winter)
Remove dead, diseased, and crossing branches
Maintain open center for air circulation
Thin fruit in early summer for better quality
pest_management: Monitor regularly for aphids and scale insects
Use integrated pest management approach
Encourage beneficial insects with diverse plantings
Apply dormant oil spray in late winter
care_instructions.harvesting: Harvest when apples are firm, fully colored, and easily separate from branch with a twist. Test ripeness by checking if seeds are dark brown.
post_harvest: Store in cool, humid conditions (32-40°F, 90-95% humidity)
Separate varieties as some ripen faster
Check stored apples regularly and remove damaged ones

fall: Rake and dispose of fallen leaves

diseases.name: Apple Scab
diseases.symptoms: Dark, scaly lesions on leaves and fruit, premature leaf drop, reduced fruit quality, olive-green to black spots that become raised and scaly
diseases.causes: Fungal infection caused by Venturia inaequalis, thrives in cool, moist conditions with temperatures 55-75°F and high humidity
prevention: Plant scab-resistant apple varieties
Ensure proper air circulation by pruning
Remove fallen leaves and debris in fall
Apply preventive fungicides in early spring
Avoid overhead watering
treatment: Apply copper-based fungicides at green tip stage
Use systemic fungicides like myclobutanil during infection periods
Remove infected plant parts immediately and dispose properly
Improve orchard sanitation practices
Apply lime sulfur spray during dormant season
diseases.immediate_action: Remove infected leaves and apply fungicide treatment immediately to prevent spread to fruit and other trees
organic_treatment: Baking soda solution (1 tsp per quart water)
Compost tea applications to boost plant immunity
Milk spray (1 part milk to 9 parts water)
diseases.favorable_conditions: Cool, moist conditions with temperatures 55-75°F, high humidity, and wet spring weather
diseases.spread_method: Wind and rain dispersal of spores, overwintering in fallen leaves

diseases.name: Fire Blight
diseases.symptoms: Blackened, wilted shoots that look burned, cankers on branches, bacterial ooze, shepherd's crook appearance of shoot tips, flowers and fruit clusters turn black
diseases.causes: Bacterial infection by Erwinia amylovora, spread by insects, rain, wind, and contaminated pruning tools during warm, humid weather
prevention: Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization which promotes susceptible growth
Prune during dormant season to avoid spreading bacteria
Use copper sprays during bloom period
Plant fire blight-resistant varieties
Disinfect pruning tools between cuts
treatment: Prune infected branches 12 inches below visible symptoms
Apply streptomycin or oxytetracycline antibiotics during bloom
Disinfect pruning tools with 70% alcohol between cuts
Remove severely infected trees to protect others
Burn or bury infected wood, do not compost
diseases.immediate_action: Prune infected areas immediately using disinfected tools and apply antibiotic treatment to save the tree and prevent spread
organic_treatment: Apply beneficial bacteria like Bacillus subtilis
diseases.favorable_conditions: Warm, humid weather with temperatures above 60°F, especially during bloom period
diseases.spread_method: Insects (especially bees), rain splash, wind, and contaminated tools

suitable_regions: Regions with adequate winter chill hours
Areas with moderate rainfall and good drainage
Northern United States and southern Canada
apple.growing_season: Spring through fall, dormant in winter
apple.maturity_time: 2-5 years to fruit production, 7-10 years for full production
apple.yield_info: 15-50 bushels per mature tree depending on variety and care

soil_requirements.drainage: Well-draining, fertile soil rich in organic matter

weather_requirements.humidity_range: Moderate humidity (40-70%) with good air circulation
weather_requirements.frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive, plant after last frost date

watering: Provide consistent moisture, 1-2 inches per week
Water at soil level to avoid wetting foliage
Maintain even soil moisture to prevent blossom end rot
Use drip irrigation or soaker hoses when possible
Avoid water stress during fruit development
fertilization: High nitrogen needs early in season for vegetative growth
Switch to phosphorus-potassium focus during fruiting
Side-dress with compost or balanced fertilizer monthly
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen during fruiting
Add calcium to prevent blossom end rot
pruning: Remove suckers that grow between main stem and branches
Prune lower leaves that touch the ground
Stake or cage plants for support
Remove diseased or damaged foliage immediately
Top plants late in season to ripen existing fruit
pest_management: Monitor for hornworms, aphids, and whiteflies
Use row covers early in season
Encourage beneficial insects with companion plants
Rotate crops annually to break pest cycles
Hand-pick large pests like hornworms
care_instructions.harvesting: Harvest when fruits show first blush of color for best flavor, or when fully red. Green tomatoes can be ripened indoors.
post_harvest: Store ripe tomatoes at room temperature
Ripen green tomatoes in paper bags with banana
Use within a week for best quality

diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (target spots) on older leaves, yellowing and leaf drop starting from bottom, fruit lesions with dark, sunken areas
diseases.causes: Fungal infection by Alternaria solani, favored by warm, humid conditions (75-85°F), stressed or older plants more susceptible
prevention: Rotate crops annually to break disease cycle
Space plants adequately for air circulation
Water at soil level, avoid wetting foliage
Apply mulch to prevent soil splash on leaves
Remove plant debris at end of season
treatment: Apply copper-based or chlorothalonil fungicides preventively
Remove infected lower leaves immediately
Improve air circulation around plants
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering
Apply fungicide every 7-14 days during humid periods
diseases.immediate_action: Remove affected leaves immediately and apply fungicide to prevent further spread up the plant
organic_treatment: Baking soda spray (1 tsp per quart water)
Compost tea to boost plant immunity
diseases.favorable_conditions: Warm temperatures (75-85°F), high humidity, leaf wetness, and plant stress
diseases.spread_method: Wind-blown spores, water splash, and infected plant debris

diseases.name: Late Blight
diseases.symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves, white fuzzy growth on undersides of leaves, rapid fruit rot, dark lesions on stems, entire plant collapse possible
diseases.causes: Oomycete pathogen Phytophthora infestans, spreads rapidly in cool, wet conditions (60-70°F), same organism that caused Irish Potato Famine
prevention: Plant certified disease-free seedlings
Ensure excellent drainage and air circulation
Apply preventive fungicides in high-risk periods
Monitor weather conditions closely for favorable disease conditions
Avoid overhead watering completely
treatment: Apply systemic fungicides like metalaxyl or dimethomorph
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Do not compost infected material
Harvest green fruit before disease spreads
Apply copper fungicides preventively
diseases.immediate_action: Emergency fungicide application and immediate removal of infected plants to prevent total crop loss and spread to neighboring plants
organic_treatment: Use resistant varieties in future plantings
diseases.favorable_conditions: Cool, wet weather with temperatures 60-70°F, high humidity (>90%), and leaf wetness for 10+ hours
diseases.spread_method: Wind-blown sporangia, water splash, and infected plant material

suitable_regions: Warm season crop in temperate climates
tomato.growing_season: Late spring through fall, warm season crop
tomato.maturity_time: 60-85 days from transplant depending on variety
tomato.yield_info: 10-15 pounds per plant for indeterminate varieties, 4-6 pounds for determinate

soil_requirements.depth_requirement: Deep soil preferred for extensive root system, minimum 2 feet

weather_requirements.humidity_range: Moderate humidity, avoid excessive moisture during tasseling
weather_requirements.sunlight_hours: Full sun essential for maximum yield, 6-8 hours minimum
weather_requirements.frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive, requires frost-free growing season

watering: Deep, infrequent watering preferred to encourage deep roots
Critical water needs during tasseling and ear formation
Provide 1-1.5 inches per week during growing season
Avoid water stress during pollination period
Reduce watering as kernels reach maturity
fertilization: Heavy nitrogen feeder, requires adequate N throughout season
Side-dress with nitrogen at knee-high stage (V6)
Apply balanced fertilizer at planting
Additional nitrogen application at tasseling
Ensure adequate phosphorus and potassium availability
pruning: Remove suckers (tillers) if desired for larger ears
Hill soil around base for additional support
Remove lower leaves only if diseased
Allow multiple ears per plant for sweet corn varieties
pest_management: Monitor for corn borer, armyworm, and rootworm
Use Bt corn varieties for lepidopteran pests
Crop rotation to manage rootworm
Beneficial insects help control aphids and other pests
Pheromone traps for monitoring adult pest populations
care_instructions.harvesting: Sweet corn ready when silks are brown and kernels are milky when punctured. Field corn harvested when kernels are hard and moisture content is 15-20%.
post_harvest: Sweet corn best used immediately after harvest
Cool quickly to preserve sugar content
Field corn should be dried to 14% moisture for storage
Store in cool, dry conditions to prevent mold

diseases.name: Corn Smut
diseases.symptoms: Large, grayish-white galls on ears, stalks, leaves, and tassels that turn black when mature and release dark spores
diseases.causes: Fungal infection by Ustilago maydis, enters through wounds caused by insects, hail, or mechanical damage, favored by warm, dry conditions followed by moisture
prevention: Avoid mechanical damage to plants during cultivation
Control corn borers and other insects that create wounds
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops
Remove infected galls before spores mature and are released
Plant resistant varieties when available
treatment: Remove and destroy infected galls immediately
No effective chemical treatment available
Focus on prevention and sanitation practices
Harvest unaffected portions of plant normally
Burn infected material, do not compost
diseases.immediate_action: Remove infected galls immediately before they release black spores to prevent spread to other plants
organic_treatment: Improve plant vigor through proper nutrition
diseases.favorable_conditions: Warm weather followed by moisture, plant stress, and mechanical wounds
diseases.spread_method: Wind dispersal of spores, overwintering spores in soil

diseases.name: Northern Leaf Blight
diseases.symptoms: Long, elliptical, gray-green lesions on leaves that can extend across entire leaf width, lesions may have dark borders
diseases.causes: Fungal pathogen Exserohilum turcicum, favored by moderate temperatures (65-80°F) and high humidity, spreads rapidly under favorable conditions
prevention: Plant resistant corn hybrids with Ht genes
Rotate with non-grass crops for 2-3 years
Bury crop residue completely to reduce inoculum
Ensure adequate plant spacing for air circulation
Avoid overhead irrigation during vulnerable periods
treatment: Apply triazole fungicides (propiconazole, tebuconazole) or strobilurin fungicides
Time applications at early symptom development for best control
Multiple applications may be needed in severe conditions
Focus on protecting upper leaves and ear leaf
Monitor weather conditions for reinfection periods
diseases.immediate_action: Apply fungicide treatment at first sign of lesions to protect yield, especially if conditions favor disease development
organic_treatment: Use resistant varieties as primary control
Improve air circulation through proper spacing
diseases.favorable_conditions: Moderate temperatures 65-80°F, high humidity, leaf wetness, and susceptible varieties
diseases.spread_method: Wind-blown conidia, rain splash, and infected crop residue

suitable_regions: Corn Belt states (Iowa, Illinois, Nebraska, Indiana) ideal
Areas with warm summers and adequate rainfall
Plains and prairie regions excellent for field corn
corn.growing_season: Late spring through fall, warm season crop
corn.maturity_time: 60-100 days depending on variety (sweet corn 60-90 days, field corn 90-120 days)
corn.yield_info: 150-200 bushels per acre for field corn, 8-12 ears per plant for sweet corn

soil_requirements.depth_requirement: 12-18 inches loose soil for tuber development

weather_requirements.frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive, plant after soil warms to 45°F

watering: Consistent moisture throughout growing season
Deep watering 1-2 times per week
Avoid overwatering which can cause tuber rot
Reduce watering 2 weeks before harvest
fertilization: Balanced fertilization with emphasis on potassium
Side-dress with compost when plants are 6 inches tall
Avoid fresh manure which can cause scab
Apply low-nitrogen fertilizer to prevent excessive foliage
pruning: Hill soil around plants as they grow
Remove flower buds to direct energy to tubers
Hill every 2-3 weeks until plants flower
Keep tubers covered to prevent greening
pest_management: Monitor for Colorado potato beetle
Rotate crops to break pest cycles
Use row covers early in season
Hand-pick potato beetles and egg masses
care_instructions.harvesting: Harvest new potatoes 2-3 weeks after flowering. Mature potatoes ready when foliage dies back naturally.

diseases.name: Late Blight
diseases.symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves, white fuzzy growth on leaf undersides, rapid blackening of foliage, tuber rot
diseases.causes: Same pathogen as tomato late blight, favored by cool, wet conditions
prevention: Plant certified disease-free seed potatoes
Ensure good air circulation
Avoid overhead watering
Apply preventive fungicides in wet weather
treatment: Apply systemic fungicides immediately
Remove infected plants
Improve drainage
Harvest tubers before disease reaches them
diseases.immediate_action: Emergency fungicide application and removal of infected plants
diseases.favorable_conditions: Cool, wet weather with high humidity

suitable_regions: Cool season crop, grows well in northern climates
potato.growing_season: Cool season crop, spring and fall plantings
potato.yield_info: 10-20 pounds per plant depending on variety and conditions

soil_requirements.drainage: Well-draining soil, tolerates various soil types

weather_requirements.humidity_range: Moderate humidity, dry conditions at harvest
weather_requirements.frost_tolerance: Winter wheat is cold hardy, spring wheat is frost sensitive

watering: Drought tolerant once established
Critical water needs during grain filling
Avoid overwatering which can cause lodging
Dry conditions preferred at harvest
fertilization: Heavy nitrogen feeder
Apply phosphorus and potassium at planting
Top-dress with nitrogen in spring for winter wheat
Avoid late nitrogen applications
pruning: No pruning required
May need to manage weeds between rows
Monitor for lodging in high-fertility situations
pest_management: Monitor for aphids, Hessian fly, and armyworms
Crop rotation helps manage soil-borne pests
Use certified seed to avoid seed-borne diseases
care_instructions.harvesting: Harvest when grain moisture is 12-14% for proper storage. Grain should be hard and golden.

diseases.name: Wheat Rust
diseases.symptoms: Orange to reddish-brown pustules on leaves and stems, can cause significant yield loss
diseases.causes: Several Puccinia species, favored by warm, humid conditions
prevention: Plant rust-resistant varieties
Monitor weather conditions
Remove volunteer wheat plants
Apply preventive fungicides if necessary
treatment: Fungicide applications during infection periods
Use systemic fungicides for best control
Multiple applications may be needed
diseases.immediate_action: Apply fungicides at first sign of infection
diseases.favorable_conditions: Warm days, cool nights, high humidity

wheat.growing_season: Fall planting for winter wheat, spring planting for spring wheat
wheat.maturity_time: Winter wheat: 7-8 months, Spring wheat: 4-5 months
wheat.yield_info: 30-60 bushels per acre depending on variety and conditions
